title: What is the electron geometry if you have 3 electron groups around the center atom? - Quora

response.answer_text: You want the electronic geometry if there are THREE pairs of electrons around a CENTRAL atom? Well, we describe a [math]sp^{2}[/math] system … and reasonably, the electron pairs, the ORBITALS, adopt a geometry that MINIMIZES electronic interaction … and thus we would predict by [math]\text{VESPER}_{\text{Valence shell electron-pair repulsion theory}}[/math] A TRIGONAL PLANAR geometry… And as you have nicely appreciated, electronic geometry MAY NOT correspond to molecular geometry… And so molecular [math]BCl_{3}[/math] with [math]sp^{2}[/math] hybridization, has trigonal planar geometry, i.e. [math]∠_{Cl-B-Cl}=120°[/math]; but dichlorocarbene, [math]Cl_{2}C:[/math] (a real molecule, but you would not be able to put it into a bottle, has a BENT geometry)…[math]∠_{Cl-C-Cl} \approx 110°[/math], that is the carbon lone pair of electrons, the which lies CLOSE to the parent carbon atom as a NON-BONDING lone pair, tends to compress [math]∠_{Cl-C-Cl}[/math] BELOW [math]120°[/math]...
